sections.title: What are prepositions?
sections.content:
Prepositions are short words that link a noun, pronoun or phrase to the rest of the sentence. They show relationships of **time** (when?), **place** (where?), **direction** (where to or from?), **manner** (how?), and more. You cannot translate them word-for-word from Czech – each preposition has many uses and English often chooses a different one.

Examples:
• Time: She arrives **at** 5 o'clock. We meet **on** Monday. I was born **in** 1995.
• Place: The book is **on** the table. He lives **in** London. We'll meet **at** the bus stop.
• Direction: I'm going **to** the station. She came **from** Paris. Put it **into** the box.
• With verbs/adjectives: I'm interested **in** music. It depends **on** you. Made **by** hand.

sections.title: The top 40 prepositions
sections.content:
Here are the 40 most common prepositions in English. Learn them in groups – time, place, movement, and fixed phrases (e.g. interested **in**, good **at**).

**1–10 (very frequent):** of, to, in, for, on, with, at, by, from, about
• **of** – belonging, part of (the capital of France; made of wood)
• **to** – direction, recipient (go to school; give to me)
• **in** – inside, time period (in the room; in 2020)
• **for** – purpose, duration (for you; for two hours)
• **on** – surface, day (on the table; on Monday)
• **with** – together, means (with a friend; cut with a knife)
• **at** – point in time/place (at 5 pm; at the door)
• **by** – agent, means, deadline (by train; by Friday)
• **from** – origin, start (from London; from Monday)
• **about** – concerning (talk about; worried about)

**11–20:** as, into, like, through, over, after, between, out, under, before
• **as** – role (work as a teacher)
• **into** – movement inside (go into the room)
• **like** – similar to (look like; sound like)
• **through** – from one side to the other (through the tunnel)
• **over** – above, across (over the bridge; over 100)
• **after** – later than (after dinner)
• **between** – in the middle of two (between A and B)
• **out** – often **out of** (get out of the car)
• **under** – below (under the table)
• **before** – earlier than (before 5 pm)

**21–30:** without, around, since, against, during, until, among, across, behind, above
• **without** – not having (without money)
• **around** – approximately, surrounding (around 10; sit around the table)
• **since** – from (time) until now (since 2020)
• **against** – opposing (against the law)
• **during** – within a period (during the meeting)
• **until** – up to a time (until tomorrow)
• **among** – in a group (among friends)
• **across** – from one side to the other (across the road)
• **behind** – at the back of (behind the door)
• **above** – higher than (above the clouds)

**31–40:** below, near, along, off, up, down, towards, within, upon, except
• **below** – lower than (below zero)
• **near** – close to (near the station)
• **along** – following a line (along the river)
• **off** – away from (fall off the chair)
• **up** / **down** – direction (up the stairs; down the hill)
• **towards** – in the direction of (towards the city)
• **within** – inside (time or space) (within an hour)
• **upon** – formal for **on** (once upon a time)
• **except** – not including (everyone except Tom)

sections.title: Types of prepositions (time, place, movement)
sections.content:
**Time** – when something happens:
• **at** + clock (at 5 o'clock, at noon)
• **on** + day/date (on Monday, on 15th March)
• **in** + month/year/season/part of day (in August, in 2020, in the morning)
• **for** + duration (for two hours)
• **since** + start point (since 2020)
• **during** + period/event (during the meeting)
• **by** = no later than (by Friday)
• **until** = up to (until tomorrow)
• **before** / **after** (before 5 pm; after dinner)

**Place (point):** **at** – at the door, at the bus stop, at home.

**Place (surface/line):** **on** – on the wall, on the table, on Main Street.

**Place (inside):** **in** – in the room, in the box, in London.

**Movement/direction:** **to** (to the station), **from** (from Paris), **into** (into the room), **out of** (out of the car), **through** (through the tunnel), **across** (across the road), **along** (along the river), **up**/**down** (up the stairs), **towards** (towards the city).

sections.title: Place: in, on, at (visual idea)
sections.content:
Think of place prepositions like this:

• **IN** = inside a space (a dot inside a circle): in the box, in the room, in London.
• **ON** = on top of a surface (a dot on a line): on the table, on the wall, on the floor.
• **AT** = at a point or place (a dot at a spot): at the door, at the bus stop, at home.

Match the situation to the right preposition: inside → in; on a surface → on; at a meeting point → at.

sections.title: Typical Czech learner errors
sections.content:
Czech prepositions don't match English one-to-one, so these mistakes are common:

• **Time:** Czech uses one preposition where English uses at/on/in. Wrong: I get up **on** 7 o'clock. She was born **at** 1995. Right: **at** 7 o'clock (exact time), **on** Monday (day), **in** 1995 (year). Remember: at + clock, on + day/date, in + month/year/season.
• **Place:** Czech 'na' can mean on, at, or to. Wrong: The book is **at** the table. We meet **on** the bus stop. Right: **on** the table (surface), **at** the bus stop (point). In = inside; on = surface; at = point.
• **Verbs + preposition:** Wrong: I'm interested **on** that. She's good **in** maths. It depends **from** the weather. Right: interested **in**, good **at**, depend **on**. These are fixed – learn them as chunks.
• **Duration:** Wrong: I've lived here **since** three years. Right: **for** three years (duration) or **since** 2020 (start point).

Tip: Don't translate the preposition word for word – learn the English pattern.

sections.title: Reference list
sections.content: You can view, print, or download a list of common prepositions (top 20, top 50, and a full list) using the button below. Use it for reference or revision.

questions.question: 'At 5 o'clock' – what type of preposition is 'at' here?
questions.explanation: 'At' with a clock time is a time preposition.

questions.question: 'The picture is on the wall.' – What does 'on' express?
questions.explanation: 'On' with a surface (wall) is place – something on a line or surface.

questions.question: Which preposition often goes with enclosed spaces (room, box, city)?
questions.explanation: 'In' is used for enclosed spaces: in the room, in the box, in London.

questions.question: We'll meet ____ the bus stop.
questions.explanation: At a point or place → at.

gapfill_simple.title: Practice: Gap fill – Simple (time and place)

questions.question: I get up ____ 7 o'clock every day.
questions.explanation: We use **at** with exact clock times (at 7 o'clock, at noon, at midnight). Use **on** for days (on Monday) and **in** for longer periods (in 1995, in summer).

questions.question: The meeting is ____ Monday.
questions.explanation: We use **on** with days of the week and dates (on Monday, on 5th March). Use **at** for clock times and **in** for months, years or seasons.

questions.question: She was born ____ 1995.
questions.explanation: We use **in** with years, months and seasons (in 1995, in January, in summer). Use **on** for specific days and **at** for clock times.

questions.question: The book is ____ the table.
questions.explanation: We use **on** when something is on top of a surface (on the table, on the wall, on the floor). Use **in** for inside a space and **at** for a point or place as a meeting point.

questions.question: He lives ____ London.
questions.explanation: We use **in** with cities, countries and enclosed or large areas (in London, in the box, in the room). Use **at** for a specific point (at the station) and **on** for a street or surface.

questions.question: We'll meet ____ the bus stop.
questions.explanation: We use **at** for a specific point or place where something happens (at the bus stop, at the door, at home). Use **in** for being inside a building or area.

questions.question: I'm going ____ the supermarket.
questions.explanation: We use **to** for movement or direction towards a place (to the supermarket, to school, to work). Use **at** when we are already there (at the supermarket).

questions.question: She's been waiting ____ two hours.
questions.explanation: We use **for** to say how long something lasts (for two hours, for a week). Use **since** when we say when it started (since 9 o'clock) and **during** when we say when it happened (during the meeting).

questions.question: I've lived here ____ 2020.
questions.explanation: We use **since** with a point in time when something started and is still true (since 2020, since Monday). Use **for** with a duration (for three years).

questions.question: The keys are ____ the drawer.
questions.explanation: We use **in** when something is inside a space (in the drawer, in the box, in the room). Use **on** for on top of a surface and **under** for underneath.

questions.question: I'll see you ____ the morning.
questions.explanation: We use **in** with parts of the day (in the morning, in the afternoon) but **at** for night (at night).

questions.question: The shop opens ____ 9 am.
questions.explanation: Exact time → at (at 9 am, at noon).

questions.question: She was born ____ 15th March.
questions.explanation: Specific date → on (on 15th March, on Monday).

questions.question: The pen is ____ the desk.
questions.explanation: On top of a surface → on.

questions.question: They live ____ the end of the street.
questions.explanation: A specific point (end of the street) → at.

questions.question: I've been learning English ____ six months.
We stayed ____ midnight.
questions.explanation: Up to a time (we stayed up to midnight) → until or till.

questions.question: The answer is ____ the bottom of the page.
questions.explanation: A specific point (bottom of the page) → at.

questions.question: The project must be finished ____ Friday.
questions.explanation: We use **by** to mean 'no later than' or 'before' a time (by Friday, by 5 pm). Use **until** when something continues up to that time (wait until Friday), and **on** for the day itself (on Friday).

questions.question: We walked right ____ the park from one side to the other to reach the station.
questions.explanation: We use **through** when we move from one side of an area or space to the other (through the park, through the tunnel). Use **across** for a surface (across the road) and **along** for following a line (along the path).

questions.question: She sat right ____ me in the cinema so we could share the popcorn.
questions.explanation: We use **beside** or **next to** when one thing is at the side of another (beside me, next to the window). Use **between** for something in the middle of two others (between you and me).

questions.question: Divide the sweets ____ the four children.
questions.explanation: We use **between** when we talk about two or more separate people or things (between the four children, between A and B). Use **among** for a general group when we don't name them individually (among the crowd).

questions.question: I'll be there ____ 9 and 10 o'clock.
questions.explanation: We use **between** for a time (or place) in the middle of two points (between 9 and 10, between Monday and Friday). Use **from...to** for a range (from 9 to 10).

questions.question: We discussed the problem ____ the meeting.
questions.explanation: We use **during** when something happens within a period or event (during the meeting, during the film). Use **for** for how long (for two hours) and **while** with a clause (while we were meeting).

questions.question: The cat is hiding ____ the sofa—you can see its tail sticking out from underneath.
questions.explanation: We use **under** when something is below or beneath another thing (under the sofa, under the table). Use **below** for a lower level and **over** for above.

questions.question: They walked ____ the bridge.
questions.explanation: We use **across** when we go from one side of a surface or area to the other (across the bridge, across the road). Use **through** for going inside something (through the tunnel) and **along** for following the length (along the bridge).

questions.question: We drove ____ the coast for miles, following the shoreline.
questions.explanation: We use **along** when we follow a line or length (along the coast, along the river, along the road). Use **through** for from one end to the other inside something, and **across** for from one side to the other.

questions.question: He arrived ____ train.
questions.explanation: We use **by** with means of transport when we say how we travel (by train, by car, by plane). Use **on** for some transport (on foot, on the bus) and **in** for others (in a car, in a taxi).

questions.question: The ball rolled ____ the table and onto the floor.
questions.explanation: Off = from on top of something down or away (off the table).

questions.question: There's a poster ____ the wall above the sofa.
questions.explanation: On a vertical surface (the wall) → on.

questions.question: We cycled ____ the river for about five miles.
The tunnel goes ____ the mountain.
questions.explanation: From one side to the other inside something (the mountain) → through.

questions.question: She stood ____ the window, looking out.
questions.explanation: At the side of → by, beside, or next to.

questions.question: The deadline is ____ the end of the week.
We had a break ____ the journey.
questions.explanation: Within the time of the journey → during.

questions.question: They ran ____ the road to the other side.
questions.explanation: From one side of a surface to the other → across.

gapfill_tricky.title: Practice: Gap fill – Tricky and idiomatic

questions.question: I'm interested ____ learning Spanish.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrase is **interested in** (interested in music, interested in learning). We don't use 'interested about' or 'interested on' – it's always **in**.

questions.question: She's good ____ maths.
questions.explanation: We say **good at** a subject or skill (good at maths, good at swimming). Use **good with** for people or tools (good with children) and **good for** when something benefits (good for you).

questions.question: We're looking ____ our keys.
questions.explanation: **Look for** means to search for or try to find (looking for our keys, look for a job). Use **look at** when we look in a direction, and **look after** for taking care of.

questions.question: It depends ____ the weather.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrase is **depend on** (it depends on the weather, it depends on you). We always use **on** after 'depend', not 'of' or 'from'.

questions.question: He's afraid ____ spiders.
questions.explanation: We say **afraid of** (afraid of spiders, afraid of the dark). Use **of** after 'afraid' when we name what we fear; we can also say 'afraid to' do something.

questions.question: I'm tired ____ waiting.
questions.explanation: We say **tired of** when we've had enough of something (tired of waiting, tired of this weather). Use **tired from** when we're physically tired because of something (tired from work).

questions.question: She insisted ____ paying the bill.
questions.explanation: The fixed phrase is **insist on** (insist on paying, insist on coming). We use **on** after 'insist' when we say what someone insists on doing or having.

questions.question: They complained ____ the noise.
questions.explanation: We say **complain about** something (complain about the noise, complain about the service). We can also say **complain to** someone (complain to the manager).

questions.question: We need to focus ____ the main point.
questions.explanation: We say **focus on** something (focus on the main point, focus on your work). Use **on** after 'focus' – we don't say 'focus in' or 'focus at'.

questions.question: The book was written ____ a famous author.
questions.explanation: In passive sentences we use **by** to introduce the person or thing that does the action (written by a famous author, made by hand). Use **by** for the agent, not 'from'.

questions.question: I need a cup ____ tea.
questions.explanation: **of** – part of / belonging (cup of tea, capital of France).

questions.question: She's proud ____ her son.
questions.explanation: **of** – after adjectives (proud of, afraid of, tired of).

questions.question: The keys are ____ the drawer.
questions.explanation: **in** – inside a space (in the drawer, in the room).

questions.question: This present is ____ you.
questions.explanation: **for** – intended for (for you, for the meeting).

questions.question: The book is ____ the table.
questions.explanation: **on** – on a surface (on the table, on the wall).

questions.question: Cut it ____ a knife.
questions.explanation: **with** – means (with a knife, with a pen).

questions.question: We'll meet ____ the bus stop.
questions.explanation: **at** – point or place (at the bus stop, at home).

questions.question: He arrived ____ train.
questions.explanation: **by** – means of transport (by train, by car).

questions.question: The book was written ____ a famous author.
We walked ____ the park.
questions.explanation: **through** – from one side to the other (through the park, through the tunnel).

questions.question: The bridge goes ____ the river.
questions.explanation: **over** – above, across (over the river, over the bridge).

questions.question: I'll be there ____ 9 and 10.
questions.explanation: **between** – in the middle of two (between 9 and 10).

questions.question: Get ____ the car quickly.
questions.explanation: **out of** – exit (get out of, out of the room).

questions.question: The cat is ____ the sofa.
questions.explanation: **under** – below (under the sofa, under the table).

questions.question: They ran ____ the road.
questions.explanation: **across** – from one side to the other (across the road).

questions.question: The keys are ____ the door.
questions.explanation: **behind** – at the back of (behind the door).

questions.question: The ball rolled ____ the table.
questions.explanation: **off** – away from a surface (off the table).

questions.question: They drove ____ the city.
questions.explanation: **towards** – in the direction of (towards the city).

questions.question: We'll finish ____ an hour.
questions.explanation: **within** – inside a time or space (within an hour).

questions.question: Once ____ a time there was a king.
They accused him ____ stealing.
questions.explanation: Accuse someone **of** something (accuse of stealing, accuse of lying).

questions.question: She suffers ____ migraines.
questions.explanation: Suffer **from** an illness or problem (suffer from headaches).

questions.question: She applied ____ the job.
questions.explanation: Apply **for** a job or place (apply for a visa).

questions.question: We arrived ____ the station at 8.
questions.explanation: Arrive **at** a place (arrive at the airport). Use **in** for cities/countries (arrive in London).

questions.question: He believes ____ climate change.
questions.explanation: Believe **in** something (believe in justice). Believe **that** + clause.

questions.question: They complained ____ the manager about the noise.
questions.explanation: Complain **to** someone (complain to the manager). Complain **about** something.

questions.question: She congratulated him ____ passing the exam.
questions.explanation: Congratulate someone **on** something (congratulate on your success).

questions.question: We consist ____ ten members.
questions.explanation: Consist **of** = be made up of (the team consists of five people).

questions.question: He decided ____ a new car.
questions.explanation: Decide **on** something (decide on a date). Decide **to** do something.

questions.question: He's good ____ languages.
questions.explanation: Good **at** a skill or subject (good at swimming).

questions.question: He's jealous ____ his brother's success.
questions.explanation: Jealous **of** someone or something (jealous of her).

questions.question: She's proud ____ her team.
questions.explanation: Proud **of** someone or something (proud of his son).

questions.question: He has a lot of experience ____ teaching.
She has a good relationship ____ her boss.
There's a solution ____ the problem.
questions.explanation: Solution **to** a problem (answer to the question).

questions.question: He made a complaint ____ the service.
He showed an interest ____ the project.
She gave a talk ____ climate change.
questions.explanation: Talk **on** or **about** something (a talk on/about health).

questions.question: There's a difference ____ the two versions.
questions.explanation: Difference **between** two things (difference between A and B).

questions.question: She has confidence ____ her ability.
questions.explanation: Confidence **in** someone or something (confidence in the team).
